metadata.title: The system clock must be synchronized continuously, or at least daily.
metadata.description: The system clock must be synchronized continuously, or at least daily.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.
metadata.description: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised. If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.

criteria.comment: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.

metadata.title: An account on the system is not password protected
metadata.description: If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log into the account without authentication. If the root user is configured without a password, the entire system may be compromised. For user accounts not using password authentication, the account must be configured with a password lock value instead of a blank or null value.

metadata.title: The system and user default umask must be 077
metadata.description: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0. This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.

metadata.description: The audit system must alert the SA in the event of an audit processing failure.

metadata.title: The audit system must aleart the SA when the audit storage volume approaches its capacity.
metadata.description:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity. If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.
Minimally, the system must log this event and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as e-mail or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.

criterion.comment: space_left_action is set to SYSLOG, EXEC, or EMAIL (and not to IGNORE, SINGLE, SUSPEND, or HALT)

metadata.title: The system must implement non-executable program stacks.
metadata.description: The system must implement non-executable program stacks.

metadata.title: Network interfaces must not be configured to allow user control.
metadata.description: Network interfaces must not be configured to allow user control.

metadata.title: The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.
metadata.description: Accepting source routed packets should be disabled for all interfaces.

metadata.title: GEN003601
metadata.description: TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately

metadata.title: The system must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol v4 (ICMPv4) echoes sent to a broadcast address.
metadata.description: Ignoring ICMP echo requests (pings) sent to broadcast / multicast addresses should be enabled or disabled as appropriate.

metadata.title: The system must not respond to ICMP timestamp requests sent to a broadcast address.
metadata.description: The processing of Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests increases the attack surface of the system. Responding to broadcast ICMP timestamp requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

criterion.comment: System is configured to ignore ICMP timestamp requests sent to a broadcast address

metadata.title: GEN003607
metadata.description: The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets

metadata.title: GEN003608
metadata.description: Proxy ARP must not be enabled on the system

metadata.title: The system must ignore IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
metadata.description: Accepting ICMP redirects should be disabled for all interfaces.

metadata.title: The system must not send IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.
metadata.description: Sending ICMP redirects should be disabled for all interfaces.

metadata.title: The system must log martian packets.
metadata.description: Logging of "martian" packets (those with impossible addresses) should be enabled on all interfaces.

metadata.title: The system must be configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
metadata.description: Sending TCP syncookies should be enabled.

metadata.title: The system must not be configured for network bridging.
metadata.description: Some systems have the ability to bridge or switch frames (link-layer forwarding) between multiple interfaces. This can be useful in a variety of situations, but if enabled when not needed, has the potential to bypass network partitioning and security.

criteria.comment: Configure the system to not use bridging.

metadata.description: SNMP Versions 1 and 2 are not considered secure. Without the strong authentication and privacy that is provided by the SNMP Version 3 User-based Security Model (USM), an attacker or other unauthorized users may gain access to detailed system management information and use that information to launch attacks against the system.

metadata.description: Syslog logs should be sent to a remote loghost

metadata.title: Ensure Only Protocol 2 Connections Allowed
metadata.description: SSH version 1 protocol support should be disabled. (and dependencies are met)

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol
metadata.description: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH client could provide access to the system with the privileges of the user running the SSH client.

metadata.title: Use Only Approved Ciphers
metadata.description: Use only approved ciphers

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to only use hmac-sha1
SSH daemon is configured to only use hmac-sha1

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers. SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured not to use CBC ciphers
metadata.description: The cipher-block chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen-plaintext attacks and must not be used

criterion.comment: SSH client is configured to use non-CBC mode encryption and the Ciphers keyword is not commented out in the SSH client configuration file
SSH client is configured to use non-CBC mode encryption and the Ciphers keyword is not commented out in the SSH client configuration file

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions

criterion.comment: SSH client is configured to only use hmac-sha1
SSH client is configured to only use hmac-sha1

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups
metadata.description: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.

criteria.comment: sshd config must restrict logins with

metadata.title: The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ssh/*key.pub is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ssh/*key is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow GSSAPI authentication

metadata.title: The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criteria.comment: must be no or not exist

criterion.comment: no GSSAPIAuthentication listed - default is no - ok

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using GSSAPI. If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation. Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation. To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow Kerberos authentication

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow host-based authentication.
metadata.description: SSH trust relationships mean a compromise on one host can allow an attacker to move trivially to other hosts.

criterion.comment: HostbasedAuthentication is not set to yes

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
metadata.description: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must use privilege separation.
metadata.description: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.
metadata.description: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
metadata.description: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection.

metadata.title: Enable a Warning Banner
metadata.description: SSH warning banner should be enabled (and dependencies are met)

criteria.comment: SSH daemon must be configured w/DOD login banner

metadata.title: The system must not be running any routing protocol daemons, unless the system is a router.
metadata.description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

criteria.comment: select daemons should not be started

metadata.title: IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled, unless the system is a router.
metadata.description: IP forwarding should be disabled.

metadata.title: GEN005610 - the system must not have IPV6 forwarding enabled

criteria.comment: ipv6 is not installed/disabled OR forwarding is off

metadata.description: Samba share authentication does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.

metadata.description: Samba must be configured to protect authenticators. If Samba passwords are not encrypted for storage, plain-text user passwords may be read by those with access to the Samba password file.

metadata.description: Guest access to shares permits anonymous access and is not permitted.

metadata.title: The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
metadata.description: Internet Network News (INN) servers access USENET newsfeeds and store newsgroup articles. INN servers use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) to transfer information from the USENET server and from the server to authorized remote hosts.

criterion.comment: System must not be running innd server
System must not be running nnrpd server

metadata.title: The /etc/news/readers.conf (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/news/readers.conf is 600 or less permissive

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: /etc/news files group ownership
metadata.description: The files in /etc/news must be group-owned by root or news

criterion.comment: check files in /etc/news are group-owned by root or news

metadata.title: The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.
metadata.description: Due to numerous security vulnerabilities that exist within Linux NIS and its successor NIS+, neither should ever be used. Both NIS and NIS+ have been obsoleted by newer authentication services such as Kerberos and LDAP.

criterion.comment: System must not be running ypbind server

metadata.title: The system must use an access control program.
metadata.description: The system must use an access control program.

metadata.title: The system's access control program must log each system access attempt.
metadata.description: If access attempts are not logged, then multiple attempts to log on to the system by an unauthorized user may go undetected.

metadata.title: The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
metadata.description: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.

metadata.title: Disable Support for SCTP
metadata.description: Support for SCTP should be disabled.

metadata.title: Disable Support for DCCP
metadata.description: Support for DCCP should be disabled.

metadata.title: The AppleTalk protocol must be disabled or not installed.
metadata.description: The AppleTalk suite of protocols is no longer in common use. Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host. Unprivileged local processes may be able to cause the system to dynamically load a protocol handler by opening a socket using the protocol.

metadata.title: Disable Support for RDS
metadata.description: Support for RDS should be disabled.

metadata.title: Disable Support for TIPC
metadata.description: Support for TIPC should be disabled.

metadata.title: The Bluetooth protocol handler must be disabled or not installed.
metadata.description: Bluetooth is a personal area network (PAN) technology. Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host. Unprivileged local processes may be able to cause the kernel to dynamically load a protocol handler by opening a socket using the protocol.

criteria.comment: The Bluetooth protocol handler must be disabled or not installed.

metadata.title: IPv6 is the next version of the Internet protocol. Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host.
metadata.description: IPv6 is the next version of the Internet protocol. Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host.

criteria.comment: Remove the capability to use IPv6 protocol handler.

metadata.title: Disable Automatic Loading of IPv6 Kernel Module
metadata.description: Automatic loading of the IPv6 kernel module should be disabled.

metadata.title: The system must not have Teredo enabled.
metadata.description: Teredo is an IPv6 transition mechanism that involves tunneling IPv6 packets encapsulated in IPv4 packets. Unauthorized tunneling may circumvent network security.

criterion.comment: System must not be running miredo

metadata.title: The DHCP client must not send dynamic DNS updates.
metadata.description: Dynamic DNS updates transmit unencrypted information about a system including its name and address and should not be used unless needed.

criteria.comment: dhclient is not installed or configured with do-forward-updates false

metadata.title: GEN007860
metadata.description: The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages

metadata.title: The 'ldd' command must be disabled unless it protects against the execution of untrusted files.
metadata.description:
The 'ldd' command provides a list of dependent libraries needed by a given binary, which is useful for troubleshooting software. Instead of parsing the binary file, some 'ldd' implementations invoke the program with a special environment variable set, which causes the system dynamic linker to display the list of libraries. Specially crafted binaries can specify an alternate dynamic linker which may cause a program to be executed instead of examined. If the program is from an untrusted source, such as in a user home directory, or a file suspected of involvement in a system compromise, unauthorized software may be executed with the rights of the user running 'ldd'.
Some 'ldd' implementations include protections that prevent the execution of untrusted files. If such protections exist, this requirement is not applicable.
An acceptable method of disabling 'ldd' is changing its mode to 0000. The SA may conduct troubleshooting by temporarily changing the mode to allow execution and running the 'ldd' command as an unprivileged user upon trusted system binaries.

criteria.comment: If the file exists and has any execute permissions, this is a finding.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS connection must require that the server provides a certificate and that this certificate has a valid trust path to a trusted CA.
metadata.description: The NSS LDAP service provides user mappings which are a vital component of system security. Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP for NSS require authentication.

criteria.comment: IF the system uses LDAP for authentication, THEN it must validate that the certificate has a valid trust path

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/insmod.
metadata.description: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/insmod.

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/modprobe.
metadata.description: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/modprobe.

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/rmmod.
metadata.description: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules - /sbin/rmmod.

metadata.title: Crontab files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/spool/cron/* is 600 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/cron.d/* is 600 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/crontab is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Files in cron script directories must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/cron.daily/* is 700 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/cron.hourly/* is 700 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/cron.monthly/* is 700 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/cron.weekly/* is 700 or less permissive

metadata.title: The SMTP service must be an up-to-date version.
metadata.description: The SMTP service version on the system must be current to avoid exposing vulnerabilities present in unpatched versions.

metadata.title: The /etc/gshadow file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The /etc/gshadow file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The /etc/gshadow file contains a list of system groups and hashes for group passwords.

criterion.comment: Check /etc/gshadow for presence of an acl.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised. If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.

criterion.comment: Check /etc/ntp.conf for presence of an acl.

metadata.title: The root account's home directory must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the unix permissions of the files.

criterion.comment: Root home directory must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: All network services daemon files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: Restricting permission on daemons will protect them from unauthorized modification and possible system compromise.

criterion.comment: /usr/sbin directory's contents must not have extended ACLs.

metadata.title: System audit tool executables must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: To prevent unauthorized access or manipulation of system audit logs, the tools for manipulating those logs must be protected.

criterion.comment: Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.
Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.
Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.
Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.
Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.
Tools used for manipulating audit logs must not have ACL's.

metadata.title: The at.deny file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The "at" daemon control files restrict access to scheduled job manipulation and must be protected. Unauthorized modification of the at.deny file could result in Denial of Service to authorized "at" users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run "at" jobs.

criterion.comment: /etc/at.deny must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. If extended ACLs are present on the system's boot loader configuration file(s), these files may be vulnerable to unauthorized access or modification, which could compromise the system's boot process.

criterion.comment: Make sure that /boot/grub/grub.conf does not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The access.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: If the access permissions are more permissive than 0640, system security could be compromised.

criterion.comment: Check to be sure that /etc/security/access.conf does not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/sysctl.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot. These settings can affect the system's security.

criterion.comment: Check to be sure that /etc/sysctl.conf does not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver. DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses. If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information. DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.

criterion.comment: The /etc/resolv.conf file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/hosts file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The /etc/hosts file (or equivalent) configures local host name to IP address mappings that typically take precedence over DNS resolution. If this file is maliciously modified, it could cause the failure or compromise of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.

criterion.comment: The /etc/hosts file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/nsswitch.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The nsswitch.conf file (or equivalent) configures the source of a variety of system security information including account, group, and host lookups. Malicious changes could prevent the system from functioning or compromise system security.

criterion.comment: The /etc/nsswitch.conf file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system ACLs can provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.

criterion.comment: The /etc/passwd file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The /etc/group file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information.

criterion.comment: The /etc/group file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: User home directories must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user files.

criterion.comment: Make sure no user home directory has an ACL

metadata.title: The /etc/shadow file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The file also contains password hashes which must not be accessible to users other than root.

criterion.comment: The /etc/shadow file must not have an extended ACL.

metadata.title: All system command files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: Restricting permissions will protect system command files from unauthorized modification. System command files include files present in directories used by the operating system for storing default system executables and files present in directories included in the system's default executable search paths.

criterion.comment: System command files in /etc must not have ACLs.
System command files in /bin must not have ACLs.
System command files in /usr/bin must not have ACLs.
System command files in /usr/lbin must not have ACLs.
System command files in /usr/usb must not have ACLs.
System command files in /sbin must not have ACLs.
System command files in /usr/sbin must not have ACLs.

metadata.title: System log files must not have extended ACLs, except as needed to support authorized software.
metadata.description: If the system log files are not protected, unauthorized users could change the logged data, eliminating its forensic value. Authorized software may be given log file access through the use of extended ACLs when needed and configured to provide the least privileges required.

criterion.comment: Make sure no file has an ACL under /var/log
Make sure no directory has an ACL under /var/log

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp command files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are critical to system security. ACLs on these files could result in unauthorized modification, which could compromise these processes and the system.

criterion.comment: Files under /var/yp must not have ACL's.

metadata.title: Skeleton files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.

criterion.comment: Files under /etc/skel must not have ACL's.

metadata.title: The cron.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: A readable and/or writeable cron.allow file by other users than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.

criterion.comment: Make sure /etc/cron.allow does not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The xinetd.conf files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.

criterion.comment: Make sure /etc/xinetd.conf does not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The xinetd.d directory must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.

criterion.comment: Make sure /etc/xinetd.conf does not have an ACL.
Make sure no entries in /etc/xinetd.d have ACL's.

metadata.title: The services file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification. If the services file has an extended ACL, it may be possible for unauthorized users to modify the file. Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.

criterion.comment: Check to see if the /etc/services file has an ACL.

metadata.title: The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.

criterion.comment: Check to see if the /etc/cups/printers.conf file has an ACL.

metadata.title: The traceroute file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: If an extended ACL exists on the traceroute executable file, it may provide unauthorized users with access to the file. Malicious code could be inserted by an attacker and triggered whenever the traceroute command is executed by authorized users. Additionally, if an unauthorized user is granted executable permissions to the traceroute command, it could be used to gain information about the network topology behind the firewall. This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information potentially leading to system and network compromise.

criterion.comment: Check to see if the /bin/traceroute file has an ACL.

metadata.title: The at.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Unauthorized modification of the at.allow file could result in Denial of Service to authorized "at" users and the granting of the ability to run "at" jobs to unauthorized users.

criterion.comment: Check to see if the /etc/at.allow file has an ACL.

metadata.title: The "at" directory must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: If the "at" directory has an extended ACL, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or to edit files containing sensitive information within the "at" directory. Unauthorized modifications could result in Denial of Service to authorized "at" jobs.

criterion.comment: Check to see if the /var/spool/at directory has an ACL.

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.

criterion.comment: Test to see if the /etc/ftpusers file has an ACL.
Test to see if the /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers file has an ACL.
Test to see if the /etc/vsftpd/ftpusers file has an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/syslog.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.

criterion.comment: The /etc/(r)syslog.conf file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp.nolimit file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.

criterion.comment: The /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/news/nnrp.access file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Excessive permissions on the nnrp.access file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.

criterion.comment: The /etc/news/nnrp.access file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Extended ACLs may provide excessive permissions on the /etc/news/passwd.nntp file, which may permit unauthorized access or modification to the NNTP configuration.

criterion.comment: The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Excessive permissions could endanger the security of the Samba configuration file and, ultimately, the system and network.

criterion.comment: The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/smbpasswd file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: Excessive permissions could endanger the security of the Samba configuration file and, ultimately, the system and network.

criterion.comment: The /etc/samba/passdb.tdb file must not have an ACL.
The /etc/samba/secrets.tdb file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The /etc/news/incoming.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Excessive permissions on the "incoming.conf" file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.

criterion.comment: The /etc/news/incoming.conf file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: All system audit files must not have extended ACLs.
metadata.description: If a user can write to the audit logs, then audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected.

criterion.comment: The audit log files must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: The Network File System (NFS) exports configuration file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files. Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.

criterion.comment: The /etc/exports file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf (or equivalent) file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The LDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.

criterion.comment: The /etc/ldap.conf file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The LDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.

criteria.comment: Criteria logic used to filter result of error when textfile objects are not found.

criterion.comment: The ldap tls_cacertdir file must not have an ACL.
The ldap tls_cacertfile file must not have an ACL.
The ldap tls_cacert file must not have an ACL.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must not have an extended ACL.
metadata.description: If a user can write to the audit logs, then audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected.

criteria.comment: Altered logic used in order to work around a result of Error when the /etc/ldap.conf is not configured with a tls_key value.

criterion.comment: The ldap tls key file must not have an ACL.
